facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 32 of 1955 was filed.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 32 of 1955. Appeal from the judgment

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and decree dated May 5, 1954 of High Court of Punjab at Chandigarh in Regular First Appeal No. 115 of 1953.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and decree dated May 5, 1954, of the High Court of Punjab at Chandigarh in Regular First Appeal No. 115 of 1953 arising out of the decree dated

facts.text: Arising out of decree dated June 6, 1953 of Court of Subordinate Judge, 1st Class, Delhi in suit No. 26 of 1953.

anchor.surface_text: arising out of the decree dated -June 6, 1953, of the Court of the Subordinate Judge, 1st Class, Delhi, in suit No. 26 of 1953. Dewan Chaman Lal and Ratan Lal Chawla, for the appellant.

facts.text: Appellant is The Fruit and Vegetable Merchants Union, Subzimandi, a registered body under the Indian Trade Unions Act.

anchor.surface_text: The sequence of events leading up to the institution of the suit by the appellant The Fruit and Vegetable Merchants Union, Su bzimandi a registered body under the Indian Trade Unions Act,

facts.text: Respondent is the Delhi Improvement Trust.

anchor.surface_text: the market called the New Fruit and Vegetable Market, Subzimandi, under the adminis- tration the respondent, the Delhi Improvement Trust,  which hereinafter will be referred to as the Trust  is Government property

facts.text: Agreement dated March 31, 1937, Exhibit D-5 between Secretary of State for India in Council and Delhi Improvement Trust for Nazul Estate land belonging to Government placed at disposal of Trust.

anchor.surface_text: By an agreement dated, March 31, 1937,  Exhibit D-5  between the Secretary of State for India in Council and the Delhi Improvement Trust, which will have to be set out in detail hereinafter and the companystruction of which is the main point in companytroversy between the parties, a certain area of the land admittedly belonging to Government was placed at the disposal of the Trust for the orderly expansion of Delhi under the supervision of a single authority.

facts.text: Letter dated May 1/2, 1939 from Chairman of Trust to Chief Commissioner enclosing resolution No. 551 dated April 24,1939, Exhibit D-15, for scheme of new Subzimandi Fruit Market on 10.87 acres.

anchor.surface_text: By a letter dated May 1/2, 1939  number exhibited but filed in the High Court at the appellate stage  the Chairman of the Trust forwarded a companyy of the resolution No. 551 dated April 24,1939,  Exhibit D-15  to the Chief Commissioner of Delhi. The resolution sets out the scheme for the companystruction of the new Subzimandi Fruit Market on a gross area of 10.87 acres

facts.text: Government is the owner of all the land included in the scheme as per resolution.

anchor.surface_text: The resolution aforesaid sets out the object and history of the scheme. It companytains the categorical statement that Government is the owner of all the land included in the scheme.

facts.text: Chief Commissioner sanctioned scheme by letter Ex. D-8 dated May 13, 1939, stating land is Government property and Trust will administer the new market.

anchor.surface_text: In answer to this companymunication from the Trust, the Chief Commissioner sent the letter  Ex. D-8  dated May 13, 1939, sanctioning under s. 22-A of the Trust Law the scheme of the New Fruit and Vegetable Market as proposed in the resolution aforesaid at a companyt number exceeding Rs. 4,73,186.

facts.text: Market leased to plaintiff for six years from May 25, 1942 at annual rent of Rs. 35,000 rising to Rs. 45,000.

anchor.surface_text: This is the genesis of the New Fruit and Vegetable Market, Subzimandi, which hereinafter will be referred to as the Market, for a period of six years with effect from May 25, 1942, at an annual rent- of Rs. 35,000 rising every year by Rs. 2,000 to Rs. 45,000 in respect of the sixth year of the lease.

facts.text: Plaintiff instituted suit on March 18, 1948 for injunction against auction of market.

anchor.surface_text: That occasioned the suit for an injunction by the plaintiff against the Trust in the Court of the Senior Subordinate Judge of Delhi, instituted on March 18, 1948.

facts.text: Interim injunction granted, then dissolved by trial court, appeal to High Court, settlement arrived evidenced by Trust resolution dated February 24, 1949 Ex. D-13.

anchor.surface_text: The Court granted the plaintiff an interim injunction restraining the defendant from putting the market to auction. The said ex parte order of injunction was companytested by the Trust with the result that the trial Court dissolved that injunction. The plaintiff carried an appeal to the High Court of Punjab at Simla. During the pendency of the appeal a settlement was arrived at between the parties and the plaintiffs offer of Rs. 1,50,000 as annual rent of the market on the expiry of the lease was accepted by the Trust. This settlement is evidenced by the resolution of the Trust dated February 24, 1949  Ex. D-13 .

facts.text: Fresh lease Ex. D-4 dated April 22, 1949 for period May 25, 1948 to March 31, 1950 at Rs. 1,50,000 annual rent.

anchor.surface_text: In pursuance of that settlement a fresh lease was executed. By the indenture Ex.D-4 dated April 22, 1949, the plaintiff was granted a fresh lease for the period May 25, 1948, to March 31, 1950, at an annual rent of Rs. 1,50,000.

facts.text: Paragraph 22 of lease Ex. D-4 admits premises owned by Government and Delhi Ajmer Merwara Rent Control Act 1947 does not apply.

anchor.surface_text: Paragraph 22 of the indenture aforesaid companytains the following important aidmission- that both the lessor and lessee agree that the premises in dispute are owned by the Government and the provisions of the Delhi Ajmer Merwara Rent. Control Act  1947  do number apply to the same.

facts.text: Trust resolution dated May 25, 1950 Ex. D-12 extended lease by two years at Rs. 2 lakhs per year.

anchor.surface_text: But the Trust by its resolution dated May 25, 1950,  Ex. D-12  aoreed only to extend the period by two years on the existing companyditions, subject to enhancement of rent to Rs. 2 lakhs per year.

facts.text: Plaintiff started proceedings under s. 8 of Control Act for fixation of standard rent.

anchor.surface_text: The plaintiff has been paying the enhanced rent of Rs. 2 lakhs per year in view of the resolution aforesaid of the Trust but has all the same started proceedings under s. 8. of the Control Act, for fixation of standard rent in respect of the market.

facts.text: Trust advertised in Hindustan Times dated March 5, 1953 inviting tenders for lease from April 1, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: The Trust got an advertisement inserted in the Hindustan Times, New Delhi, dated March 5, 1953, inviting tenders for the lease of the market for a period of three years from April 1, 1953.

facts.text: Plaintiff instituted present suit on March 9, 1953 for permanent injunction restraining eviction.

anchor.surface_text: That was the cause of action for the plaintiff to institute the present suit on March 9, 1953. The plaintiffs prayer in the plaint is that a decree for a permanent injunction may be passed in favour of the plaintiff restraining the defendant from evicting the plaintiff from the market.

facts.text: Both courts below held property belongs to Government within s.3(a) of Rent Control Act 1952.

anchor.surface_text: Both the companyrts below have answered that issue in the affirmative, that is to say, in favour of the defendant.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds market and land is Government property, Control Act not applicable.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, therefore, it cannot be said that either under the provisions of the Improvement Act or in accordance with the terms of the agreement  Ex. D-5  or the two taken together, the market became the property of the Trust.

facts.text: Market constructed with Government funds advanced as loan to Trust.

anchor.surface_text: It was in pursuance of the terms aforesaid that the scheme of the building of the market in question was put through at an estimate. companyt of a little less than five lakhs of rupees. It is clear upon the terms of the agreement shortly set out above that the market was companystructed by the Trust on Government land with Government funds advanced by way of loan at interest.

facts.text: Trust repaid the entire amount advanced by Government for construction.

anchor.surface_text: especially in view of the fact that, as admitted by the defendants companynsel at the trial, the Trust had repaid the entire amount of five lakhs odd advanced by Government for the companystruction of the market.

facts.text: No title to land or buildings vested in Trust per court finding.

anchor.surface_text: We have already numbericed the relevant portions of the companyrespondence that passed between Government and the Trust to show that though at the initial stages the Trust proposed that the ownership of the market should vest in the Trust, the final terms agreed between the parties in accordance with the provisions of s. 54A left the ownership with Government.

facts.text: Certificate granted by High Court for appeal to Supreme Court on substantial question of law.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal has been brought to this Court on a certificate granted by the High Court of Judicature of the State of Punjab that the case involved a substantial question of law as to the legal status of the respondent vis a vis the Government.

issues.text: whether the Delhi and Ajmer Rent Control Act, XXXVIII of 1952 is applicable to the premises in question

anchor.surface_text: The main question for determination in this appeal from the courts below is whether the Delhi and Ajmer Rent Control Act, XXXVIII of 1952  which hereinafter will be referred to as the Control Act  is applicable to the premises in question. The courts below have come to the conclusion that in view of the provisions section 3 a  of the Control Act the market called the New Fruit and Vegetable Market, Subzimandi, under the adminis-

issues.text: Whether the property in dispute belongs to the Government within the meaning of s. 3(a) of the Rent Control Act, 1952

anchor.surface_text: On those pleadings a number of issues were joined between the parties of which the most important is issue No. 1- Whether the property in dispute belongs to the Government within the meaning of s. 3  a  of the Rent Control Act, 1952 Both the courts below have answered that issue in the affirmative, that is to say, in favour of the defendant.

issues.text: whether title to the land on which the market is situate has become vested in the Trust

anchor.surface_text: The question as to in whom the title to the market in question vests may be discussed in two parts,  1  title to the land on which the market is situate, and  2  title to the buildings admittedly constructed by the Trust. Adverting first to the question of title in respect of the land, it is common ground that before it was placed at the disposal of the Trust it was Government property.

issues.text: whether title to the buildings admittedly constructed by the Trust is vested in the Trust

anchor.surface_text: We turn now to the question whether apart from title to the land, title to the building standing upon the land is vested in the Trust. In order to examine the contentions raised on behalf of the appellant-it is necessary to set out the remaining portion of the terms of the indenture aforesaid.

issues.text: whether the Trust is the statutory agent of the Government

anchor.surface_text: On the other hand, it has been argued on behalf of the defendant-respondent that the Trust is the statutory agent of the Government and has-to function in accordance with the provisions of the statute aforesaid, namely, the Improvement Act. The agency was created under the provisions of s. 54A  1  of the Improvement Act, the terms of the agreement being incorporated in the indenture, Ex. D-5, dated March 31 1937.

issues.text: what is the meaning of the word 'vest' in the context of the relevant statutory provisions

anchor.surface_text: The word vest is a word, at least of ambiguous import. Prima facie vesting in possession is the more natural meaning.

arguments.claim: Word 'vest' has variable meaning depending on context; does not always mean absolute title

anchor.surface_text: The word vest is a word, at least of ambiguous import. Prima facie vesting in possession is the more natural meaning. [...] It would thus appear that the word vest has number got a fixed connotation, meaning in all cases that the property is owned by the person or the authority in whom it vests.

arguments.claim: Trust holds Nazul Estate on behalf of Government as agent per agreement terms; no transfer of title

anchor.surface_text: These words cannot be construed as transferring title to the Nazul Estate from Government to the Trust. They amount to constituting the Trust as an agent of the Government to hold possession of the property and to manage the same for the purpose for which the Trust had been created.

arguments.claim: s.54A does not convey title; merely places property at disposal of Trust per agreed terms

anchor.surface_text: Placing the property at the disposal of the Trust does number signify that Government had divested itself of its title to the property and transferred the same to the Trust.

arguments.claim: Vesting under Improvement Act ss.45-48,54A is for limited purpose of scheme execution, not full ownership

anchor.surface_text: The vesting of such property is only for the purpose of executing any improvement scheme which it has undertaken and riot with a view to clothing it with complete title.

arguments.claim: Market constructed on Govt land with Govt loan funds; structure belongs to Govt; analogous to fixtures in Bhatia Co-op case

anchor.surface_text: The law. of fixtures under s. 108 of the Transfer of Property Act may be different from the English law, but s. 108 is subject to any agreement that the parties may choose to make. Here, by the agreement the building became part of the land and the property of the lessor

holdings.text: The Delhi and Ajmer Rent Control Act, XXXVIII of 1952 is not applicable to the premises in question as they are Government property under section 3(a) of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: On those pleadings a number of issues were joined between the parties of which the most important is issue No. 1- Whether the property in dispute belongs to the Government within the meaning of s. 3  a  of the Rent Control Act, 1952 Both the courts below have answered that issue in the affirmative, that is to say, in favour of the defendant.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Both lower courts held property is Government-owned under s.3(a); Supreme Court affirms after analyzing s.54A Improvement Act, agreement Ex.D-5, and correspondence showing no title transfer to Trust.

holdings.text: The property in dispute belongs to the Government within the meaning of s. 3(a) of the Rent Control Act, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: Both the courts below have answered that issue in the affirmative, that is to say, in favour of the defendant.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Land was Government Nazul Estate placed at Trust's disposal under s.54A without title transfer; buildings constructed with Government loan on Government land; Trust repaid loan but no ownership vested.

holdings.text: No title to the land on which the market stands was conveyed by Government to the Trust.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent contests this proposition and contends that there are no words in the statute or in the agreement which either separately or together can be said to have transferred the pre-existing title of the Government to the Trust. It is pointed out on behalf of the respondent that section 54A only authorises Government to place the land in question at the disposal of the Trust

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.54A authorizes placing land at disposal per agreed terms (Ex.D-5) without conveyance words; Trust holds as agent to manage; powers to sell/lease limited by Government conditions.

holdings.text: Title to the buildings constructed by the Trust did not vest in the Trust; the market did not become Trust property.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, therefore, it cannot be said that either under the provisions of the Improvement Act or in accordance with the terms of the agreement  Ex. D-5  or the two taken together, the market became the property of the Trust.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Buildings on Government land funded by Government loan at interest; repaid loan does not confer title; fixtures become lessor's per agreement and s.108 TPA; analogous to Bhatia Co-op case.

holdings.text: The Trust is the statutory agent of the Government holding and managing the property under s.54A Improvement Act and Ex.D-5.

anchor.surface_text: These words cannot be construed as transferring title to the Nazul Estate from Government to the Trust. They amount to constituting the Trust as an agent of the Government to hold possession of the property and to manage the same for the purpose for which the Trust had been created.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.54A places property at disposal to hold per terms; Ex.D-5 constitutes agency; limited powers, accounts, surplus to Government consistent with agency not ownership.

holdings.text: The word 'vest' has a variable meaning depending on context; does not always signify absolute ownership or title.

anchor.surface_text: The word vest is a word, at least of ambiguous import. Prima facie vesting in possession is the more natural meaning. [...] It would thus appear that the word vest has not got a fixed connotation, meaning in all cases that the property is owned by the person or the authority in whom it vests.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Illustrated by English and Indian precedents (e.g., insolvency vesting limited, land acquisition absolute); in Improvement Act context, vesting for scheme execution/possession, not full title.

holdings.text: Vesting under Improvement Act (ss.45-48,54A) is for limited purpose of executing improvement schemes, not conferring complete title.

anchor.surface_text: The vesting of such property is only for the purpose of executing any improvement scheme which it has undertaken and not with a view to clothing it with complete title.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Provisions empower Trust for schemes; vesting contextual, not absolute ownership; consistent with agency role.

precedents.citation: Richardson v. Robertson 1862 6 L.T. 75, at P. 78

anchor.surface_text: In this connection reference may be made to the following observations of Lord Cranworth in Richardson v. Robertson  1  The word vest is a word, at least of ambiguous import. Prima facie vesting in possession is the more natural meaning.

precedents.cited_proposition: The word 'vest' is a word of ambiguous import and prima facie means vesting in possession rather than obtaining an absolute right
precedents.cited_holding: The word vest is a word, at least of ambiguous import. Prima facie vesting in possession is the more natural meaning...

anchor.surface_text: The following words of Willes, J. in Hinde v. Charlton 1  are relevant- words, which in terms vested -the freehold in persons appointed to perform some public duties, such as canal companies and boards of health, have been held satisfied by giving to such persons the control over the soil which was necessary to the carrying out the objects of the Act without giving them the freehold

precedents.cited_proposition: 'vest' does not convey a freehold title but only a right in the nature of an easement or control necessary for public duties
precedents.cited_holding: words, which in terms vested the freehold in persons appointed to perform some public duties... have been held satisfied by giving to such persons the control over the soil... without giving them the freehold

anchor.surface_text: In the case of Coverdale v. Charlton  2 , the Court of Appeal on a consideration of the provisions of the Public Health Act, 1875 (38 and 39 Vict. c. 55) with particular reference to s. 149, has made the following observations at p. 116-

precedents.cited_proposition: The word 'vest' in s. 149 of Public Health Act means vesting qua street, not vesting of soil or right to soil
precedents.cited_holding: What then is the meaning of the word vest in this section? ... the street vests in the local board qua street not that any soil or any right to the soil or surface vests

precedents.citation: In re Brown a lunatic 1895 2 Ch. 666

anchor.surface_text: Referring to the provisions of s. 134 of the Lunacy Act, 1890 (53 & 54 Vict. c. 5) in the case of In re Brown a lunatic  3  it has been laid down by Lindley, L. J., that the word vested in that section included the right to obtain and deal with without being actual owner of the lunatics personal estate.

precedents.cited_proposition: The word 'vested' includes the right to obtain and deal with property without being the actual owner
precedents.cited_holding: the word vested in that section included the right to obtain and deal with without being actual owner of the lunatics personal estate

precedents.citation: Finchley Electric Light Company v. Finchley Urban District Council 1903 1 Ch. 437

anchor.surface_text: In the case of Finchley Electric Light Company v. Finchley Urban District Council 1 , adverting to the provisions of s. 149 of the Public Health Act, 1875, supra Romer, L.J., has made the following observations at pp. 443 and 444-

precedents.case_name: Finchley Electric Light Company v Finchley Urban District Council
precedents.cited_proposition: s. 149 Public Health Act vests in urban authority only so much soil as necessary for control, protection and maintenance of street as highway, not full fee rights
precedents.cited_holding: It was not by that section intended to vest in the urban authority... the full rights in fee over the street... only intended to vest... so much of the actual soil of the street as might be necessary for the control, protection, and maintenance of the street as a highway

precedents.citation: Tunbridge Wells Corporation v. Baird 1896 A.C. 434

anchor.surface_text: For that proposition it is sufficient to refer to what was said by Lord Halsbury, L. C., and by Lord Herschell in Tunbridge Wells Corporation v. Baird 2  I That section has nothing to do with title it is not considering a question of title.

precedents.cited_proposition: Section has nothing to do with title; no matter what the title is, it considers how much shall vest in the authority
precedents.cited_holding: That section has nothing to do with title it is not considering a question of title. No matter what the title is of the person who owns the street, the section is only considering how much of the street shall vest in the urban authority

precedents.citation: Bhatia Co-operative Housing Society Ltd. v. D. C. Patel 1953 S.C.R. 185

anchor.surface_text: In this connection reference may be made to the decision of this Court in Bhatia Co-operative Housing Society Ltd. v. D. C. Patel 1 . The case is not on all fours with the facts of the present case. But the following observations of Das J. as he then was at p. 195 of the report are pertinent-

precedents.case_name: Bhatia Co-operative Housing Society Ltd v D C Patel
precedents.cited_proposition: A building erected by lessee on lessor's land becomes the property of the lessor by agreement
precedents.cited_holding: It is true that the lessee erected the building at his own cost but he did so for the lessor and on the lessors land on agreed terms. ... By the agreement the building became the property of the lessor
